question.text: For a reaction <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>X</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>Y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>Z</mi><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>0</mn><mi>mol</mi></math> of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>mol</mi></math> of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>mol</mi></math> of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math> were taken in a <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></math> vessel and allowed to react. At equilibrium, the concentration of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Z</mi></math> was <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>0</mn><msup><mi>molL</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>. the equilibrium constant of the reaction is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>…</mo><mo>…</mo><mo>…</mo><mo>…</mo><mfrac><mi>x</mi><mn>15</mn></mfrac><mo>.</mo></math> The value of x is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>…</mo><mo>…</mo><mo>.</mo></math>

solution.text:
x   +   y=   2 z

t=0 1mol  1.5mol  0.5mol

Since moles of Z are increased at equilibrium therefore reaction goes in forward direction to attain the
equilibrium.
